00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 PGfunctionevaluators.pl - Macros that generate function answer evaluators.
00020 
00021 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00022 
00023     ANS(fun_cmp($answer_or_answer_array_ref, %options));
00024 
00025     ANS(function_cmp($correctEqn, $var, $llimit, $ulimit, $relTol, $numPoints, $zeroLevel,
00026                      $zeroLevelTol));
00027     ANS(function_cmp_up_to_constant($correctEqn, $var, $llimit, $ulimit, $relpercentTol, 
00028                                     $numOfPoints, $maxConstantOfIntegration, $zeroLevel, 
00029                                     $zeroLevelTol));
00030     ANS(function_cmp_abs($correctFunction, $var, $llimit, $ulimit, $absTol, $numOfPoints));
00031     ANS(function_cmp_up_to_constant_abs($correctFunction, $var, $llimit, $ulimit,
00032                                         $absTol, $numOfPoints, $maxConstantOfIntegration));
00033 
00034 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00035 
00036 Function answer evaluators take in a function, compare it numerically to a
00037 correct function, and return a score. They can require an exactly equivalent
00038 function, or one that is equal up to a constant. They can accept or reject an
00039 answer based on specified tolerances for numerical deviation.
00040 
00041 The general function answer evaluator is fun_cmp(). It takes a hash of named
00042 options as parameters. There are also several specific function_cmp_*() answer
00043 evaluators for use in common situations which feature a simplified syntax.
00044 
00045 =head2 MathObjects and answer evaluators
00046 
00047 The MathObjects system provides a Formula->cmp() method that produce answer
00048 evaluators for function comparisons. fun_cmp() has been rewritten to use
00049 Formula->cmp() to produce the answer evaluator. It is recommended that you use
00050 the Formula object's cmp() method directly if possible.
00051 
00052 =cut
00053 
00054 BEGIN { be_strict() }
00055 
00056 # Until we get the PG cacheing business sorted out, we need to use
00057 # PG_restricted_eval to get the correct values for some(?) PG environment
00058 # variables. We do this once here and place the values in lexicals for later
00059 # access.
00060 my $Context;
00061 my $functAbsTolDefault;
00062 my $functLLimitDefault;
00063 my $functMaxConstantOfIntegration;
00064 my $functNumOfPoints;
00065 my $functRelPercentTolDefault;
00066 my $functULimitDefault;
00067 my $functVarDefault;
00068 my $functZeroLevelDefault;
00069 my $functZeroLevelTolDefault;
00070 my $inputs_ref;
00071 my $useOldAnswerMacros;
00072 my $user_context;
00073 sub _PGfunctionevaluators_init {
00074     $functAbsTolDefault            = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functAbsTolDefault}/);
00075     $functLLimitDefault            = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functLLimitDefault}/);
00076     $functMaxConstantOfIntegration = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functMaxConstantOfIntegration}/);
00077     $functNumOfPoints              = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functNumOfPoints}/);
00078     $functRelPercentTolDefault     = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functRelPercentTolDefault}/);
00079     $functULimitDefault            = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functULimitDefault}/);
00080     $functVarDefault               = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functVarDefault}/);
00081     $functZeroLevelDefault         = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functZeroLevelDefault}/);
00082     $functZeroLevelTolDefault      = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{functZeroLevelTolDefault}/);
00083     $inputs_ref                    = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{inputs_ref}/);
00084     $useOldAnswerMacros            = PG_restricted_eval(q/$envir{useOldAnswerMacros}/);
00085     unless ($useOldAnswerMacros) {
00086         $user_context = PG_restricted_eval(q/\%context/);
00087         $Context = sub { Parser::Context->current($user_context, @_) };
00088     }
00089 }
00090 
00091 =head1 fun_cmp
00092 
00093     ANS(fun_cmp($answer_or_answer_array_ref, %options));
00094 
00095 Compares a function or a list of functions, using a named hash of options to set
00096 parameters. This can make for more readable code than using the function_cmp()
00097 style, but some people find one or the other easier to remember.
00098 
00099 =head2 Options
00100 
00101 $answer_or_answer_array_ref can either be a string scalar representing the
00102 correct formula or a reference to an array of string scalars. If multiple
00103 formulas are provided, fun_cmp() will return a list of answer evaluators, one
00104 for each answer specified. The answer can contain functions, pi, e, and
00105 arithmetic operations. However, the correct answer string follows a slightly
00106 stricter syntax than student answers; specifically, there is no implicit
00107 multiplication. So the correct answer must be "3*x" rather than "3 x". Students
00108 can still enter "3 x".
00109 
00110 %options is a hash containing options that affect the way the comparison is
00111 performed. All hash items are optional. Allowed options are:
00112 
00113 =over
00114 
00115 =item mode
00116 
00117 This determines the evaluation mode. The recognized modes are:
00118 
00119 =over
00120 
00121 =item std (default)
00122 
00123 Function must match exactly.
00124 
00125 =item antider
00126 
00127 Function must match up to a constant.
00128 
00129 =back
00130 
00131 =item tol
00132 
00133 An absolute tolerance value. When the student and correct functions are
00134 evaluated,  the result for each evaluation point must be within a fixed distance
00135 from the correct answer to qualify. For example, an absolute tolerance of 5
00136 means that any result which is +-5 of the correct answer qualifies as correct.
00137 abstol is accepted as a synonym for tol.
00138 
00139 =item relTol
00140 
00141 A relative tolerance. Relative tolerances are given in percentages. A relative
00142 tolerance of 1 indicates that when the student's function are evaluated, the
00143 result of evaluation at each point must be within within 1% of the correct
00144 answer to qualify as correct. In other words, a student answer is correct when
00145 
00146     abs(studentAnswer - correctAnswer) <= abs(.01*relTol*correctAnswer)
00147 
00148 tol and relTol are mutually exclusive. reltol is also accpeted as a synonym for
00149 relTol.
00150 
00151 =item zeroLevel, zeroLevelTol
00152 
00153 zeroLevel and zeroLevelTol specify a alternative absolute tolerance to use when
00154 the correct answer is very close to zero.
00155 
00156 If the correct answer has an absolute value less than or equal to zeroLevel,
00157 then the student answer must be, in absolute terms, within zeroLevelTol of
00158 correctAnswer, i.e.,
00159 
00160     abs(studentAnswer - correctAnswer) <= zeroLevelTol
00161 
00162 In other words, if the correct answer is very near zero, an absolute tolerance
00163 will be used. One must do this to handle floating point answers very near zero,
00164 because of the inaccuracy of floating point arithmetic. However, the default
00165 values are almost always adequate.
00166 
00167 =item var
00168 
00169 The var parameter can contain a number, a string, or a reference to an array of
00170 variable names. If it contains a number, the variables are named automatically
00171 as follows:
00172 
00173      var | variables used     
00174     -----+--------------------
00175      1   | x                  
00176      2   | x, y               
00177      3   | x, y, z            
00178      4+  | x_1, x_2, x_3, ... 
00179 
00180 If the var parameter contains a reference to an array of variable names, then
00181 the number of variables is determined by the number of items in the array. For example:
00182 
00183     var=>['r','s','t']
00184 
00185 If the var parameter contains a string, the string is used as the name of a
00186 single variable. Hence, the following are equivalent:
00187 
00188     var=>['t']
00189     var=>'t'
00190 
00191 vars is recognied as a synonym for var. The default is a single variable, x.
00192 
00193 =item limits
00194 
00195 Limits are specified with the limits parameter. If you specify limits for one
00196 variable, you must specify them for all variables. The limit parameter must be a
00197 reference to an array of arrays of the form C<[$lower_limit. $upper_limit]>,
00198 each array corresponding to the lower and upper endpoints of the (half-open)
00199 domain of one variable. For example,
00200 
00201     vars=>2, limits=>[[0,2], [-3,8]]
00202 
00203 would cause x to be evaluated in [0,2) and y to be evaluated in [-3,8). If only
00204 one variable is being used, you can write either:
00205 
00206     limits => [[0,3]]
00207     limits => [0,3]
00208 
00209 domain is recognized as a synonym for limits.
00210 
00211 =item test_points
00212 
00213 In some cases, the problem writer may want to specify the points used to check a
00214 particular function.  For example, if you want to use only integer values, they
00215 can be specified.  With one variable, either of these two forms work:
00216 
00217     test_points=>[1,4,5,6]
00218     test_points=>[[1,4,5,6]]
00219 
00220 With more variables, specify the list for the first variable, then the second,
00221 and so on:
00222 
00223     vars=>['x','y'], test_points=>[[1,4,5],[7,14,29]]".
00224 
00225 If the problem writer wants random values which need to meet some special
00226 restrictions (such as being integers), they can be generated in the problem:
00227 
00228     test_points=>[random(1,50), random(1,50), random(1,50), random(1,50)]
00229 
00230 Note that test_points should not be used for function checks which involve
00231 parameters (either explicitly given by "params", or as antiderivatives).
00232 
00233 
00234 =item numPoints
00235 
00236 The number of sample points to use when evaluating the function.
00237 
00238 =item maxConstantOfIntegration
00239 
00240 Maximum size for the constant of integration (in antider mode).
00241 
00242 =item params
00243 
00244 A reference to an array of "free" parameters which can be used to adapt the
00245 correct answer to the submitted answer. (e.g. ['c'] for a constant of
00246 integration in the answer x^3/3+c.
00247 
00248 =item debug
00249 
00250 If set to one, extra debugging information will be output.
00251 
00252 =back
00253 
00254 =head2 Examples
00255 
00256     # standard compare, variable is x
00257     fun_cmp("3*x");
00258 
00259     # standard compare, defaults used for all three functions
00260     fun_cmp(["3*x", "4*x+3", "3*x**2"]);
00261 
00262     # standard compare, variable is t
00263     fun_cmp("3*t", var=>'t');
00264 
00265     # x, y and z are the variables
00266     fun_cmp("5*x*y*z", var=>3);
00267 
00268     # student answer must match up to constant (i.e., 5x+C)
00269     fun_cmp("5*x", mode=>'antider');
00270 
00271     # x is evaluated in [0,2), y in [5,7)
00272     fun_cmp(["3*x*y", "4*x*y"], limits=>[[0,2], [5,7]]);
00273 
00274 =cut
00275 
00276 sub fun_cmp {
00277     my $correctAnswer = shift @_;
00278     my %opt           = @_;
00279 
00280     assign_option_aliases( \%opt,
00281                 'vars'      =>  'var',    # set the standard option 'var' to the one specified as vars
00282                 'domain'    =>  'limits', # set the standard option 'limits' to the one specified as domain
00283                 'reltol'    =>  'relTol',
00284                 'param'     =>  'params',
00285     );
00286 
00287     set_default_options(    \%opt,
00288                 'var'                   =>  $functVarDefault,
00289                 'params'                =>  [],
00290                 'limits'                =>  [[$functLLimitDefault, $functULimitDefault]],
00291                 'test_points'   => undef,
00292                 'mode'                  =>  'std',
00293                 'tolType'               =>      (defined($opt{tol}) ) ? 'absolute' : 'relative',
00294                 'tol'                   =>  .01, # default mode should be relative, to obtain this tol must not be defined
00295                 'relTol'                =>  $functRelPercentTolDefault,
00296                 'numPoints'             =>  $functNumOfPoints,
00297                 'maxConstantOfIntegration'  =>  $functMaxConstantOfIntegration,
00298                 'zeroLevel'             =>  $functZeroLevelDefault,
00299                 'zeroLevelTol'          =>  $functZeroLevelTolDefault,
00300                 'debug'                 =>  0,
00301                 'diagnostics'                           =>      undef,
00302      );
00303 
00304     # allow var => 'x' as an abbreviation for var => ['x']
00305     my %out_options = %opt;
00306     unless ( ref($out_options{var}) eq 'ARRAY' || $out_options{var} =~ m/^\d+$/) {
00307         $out_options{var} = [$out_options{var}];
00308     }
00309     # allow params => 'c' as an abbreviation for params => ['c']
00310     unless ( ref($out_options{params}) eq 'ARRAY' ) {
00311         $out_options{params} = [$out_options{params}];
00312     }
00313     my ($tolType, $tol);
00314     if ($out_options{tolType} eq 'absolute') {
00315         $tolType = 'absolute';
00316         $tol = $out_options{'tol'};
00317         delete($out_options{'relTol'}) if exists( $out_options{'relTol'} );
00318     } else {
00319         $tolType = 'relative';
00320         $tol = $out_options{'relTol'};
00321         delete($out_options{'tol'}) if exists( $out_options{'tol'} );
00322     }
00323 
00324     my @output_list = ();
00325     # thread over lists
00326     my @ans_list = ();
00327 
00328     if ( ref($correctAnswer) eq 'ARRAY' ) {
00329         @ans_list = @{$correctAnswer};
00330     }
00331     else {
00332         push( @ans_list, $correctAnswer );
00333     }
00334 
00335     # produce answer evaluators
00336     foreach my $ans (@ans_list) {
00337         push(@output_list,
00338             FUNCTION_CMP(
00339                     'correctEqn'        =>  $ans,
00340                     'var'               =>  $out_options{'var'},
00341                     'limits'            =>  $out_options{'limits'},
00342                     'tolerance'         =>  $tol,
00343                     'tolType'           =>  $tolType,
00344                     'numPoints'         =>  $out_options{'numPoints'},
00345                     'test_points' =>  $out_options{'test_points'},
00346                     'mode'              =>  $out_options{'mode'},
00347                     'maxConstantOfIntegration'  =>  $out_options{'maxConstantOfIntegration'},
00348                     'zeroLevel'         =>  $out_options{'zeroLevel'},
00349                     'zeroLevelTol'      =>  $out_options{'zeroLevelTol'},
00350                     'params'            =>  $out_options{'params'},
00351                     'debug'             =>  $out_options{'debug'},
00352                         'diagnostics'               =>  $out_options{'diagnostics'} ,
00353             ),
00354         );
00355     }
00356 
00357     return (wantarray) ? @output_list : $output_list[0];
00358 }
00359 
00360 =head1 Single-variable Function Comparisons
00361 
00362 There are four single-variable function answer evaluators: "normal," absolute
00363 tolerance, antiderivative, and antiderivative with absolute tolerance. All
00364 parameters (other than the correct equation) are optional.
00365 
00366 =head2 function_cmp
00367 
00368     ANS(function_cmp($correctEqn, $var, $llimit, $ulimit, $relTol, $numPoints,
00369                      $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00370 
00371 function_cmp() uses standard comparison and relative tolerance. It takes a
00372 string representing a single-variable function and compares the student answer
00373 to that function numerically. $var, $relTol, $numPoints, $zeroLevel, and 
00374 $zeroLevelTol are equivalent to the identically-named options to fun_cmp(),
00375 above. $llimit and $ulimit are combined to form the value of limits above.
00376 
00377 =cut
00378 
00379 sub function_cmp {
00380     my ($correctEqn,$var,$llimit,$ulimit,$relPercentTol,$numPoints,$zeroLevel,$zeroLevelTol) = @_;
00381 
00382     if ( (scalar(@_) == 3) or (scalar(@_) > 8) or (scalar(@_) == 0) ) {
00383         function_invalid_params( $correctEqn );
00384     }
00385     else {
00386         FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'                    =>  $correctEqn,
00387                 'var'                       =>  $var,
00388                 'limits'                    =>  [$llimit, $ulimit],
00389                 'tolerance'                 =>  $relPercentTol,
00390                 'tolType'                   =>  'relative',
00391                 'numPoints'                 =>  $numPoints,
00392                 'mode'                      =>  'std',
00393                 'maxConstantOfIntegration'          =>  0,
00394                 'zeroLevel'                 =>  $zeroLevel,
00395                 'zeroLevelTol'                  =>  $zeroLevelTol
00396                     );
00397     }
00398 }
00399 
00400 =head2 function_cmp_up_to_constant
00401 
00402     ANS(function_cmp_up_to_constant($correctEqn, $var, $llimit, $ulimit,
00403                                     $relpercentTol, $numOfPoints,
00404                                     $maxConstantOfIntegration, $zeroLevel,
00405                                     $zeroLevelTol));
00406 
00407 function_cmp_up_to_constant() uses antiderivative compare and relative
00408 tolerance. All but the first argument are optional. All options work exactly
00409 like function_cmp(), except of course $maxConstantOfIntegration. It will accept
00410 as correct any function which differs from $correctEqn by at most a constant;
00411 that is, if
00412 
00413     $studentEqn = $correctEqn + C, where C <= $maxConstantOfIntegration
00414 
00415 the answer is correct.
00416 
00417 =cut
00418 
00419 sub function_cmp_up_to_constant {   ## for antiderivative problems
00420     my ($correctEqn,$var,$llimit,$ulimit,$relPercentTol,$numPoints,$maxConstantOfIntegration,$zeroLevel,$zeroLevelTol) = @_;
00421 
00422     if ( (scalar(@_) == 3) or (scalar(@_) > 9) or (scalar(@_) == 0) ) {
00423         function_invalid_params( $correctEqn );
00424     }
00425     else {
00426         FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'                    =>  $correctEqn,
00427                 'var'                       =>  $var,
00428                 'limits'                    =>  [$llimit, $ulimit],
00429                 'tolerance'                 =>  $relPercentTol,
00430                 'tolType'                   =>  'relative',
00431                 'numPoints'                 =>  $numPoints,
00432                 'mode'                      =>  'antider',
00433                 'maxConstantOfIntegration'          =>  $maxConstantOfIntegration,
00434                 'zeroLevel'                 =>  $zeroLevel,
00435                 'zeroLevelTol'                  =>  $zeroLevelTol
00436             );
00437     }
00438 }
00439 
00440 =head2 function_cmp_abs
00441 
00442     ANS(function_cmp_abs($correctFunction, $var, $llimit, $ulimit, $absTol, $numOfPoints));
00443 
00444 function_cmp_abs() uses standard compare and absolute tolerance. All but the
00445 first argument are optional. $absTol defines the absolute tolerance value. See
00446 the corresponding option to fun_cmp(), above. All other options work exactly as
00447 for function_cmp().
00448 
00449 =cut
00450 
00451 sub function_cmp_abs {          ## similar to function_cmp but uses absolute tolerance
00452     my ($correctEqn,$var,$llimit,$ulimit,$absTol,$numPoints) = @_;
00453 
00454     if ( (scalar(@_) == 3) or (scalar(@_) > 6) or (scalar(@_) == 0) ) {
00455         function_invalid_params( $correctEqn );
00456     }
00457     else {
00458         FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'            =>  $correctEqn,
00459                 'var'               =>  $var,
00460                 'limits'            =>  [$llimit, $ulimit],
00461                 'tolerance'         =>  $absTol,
00462                 'tolType'           =>  'absolute',
00463                 'numPoints'         =>  $numPoints,
00464                 'mode'              =>  'std',
00465                 'maxConstantOfIntegration'  =>  0,
00466                 'zeroLevel'         =>  0,
00467                 'zeroLevelTol'          =>  0
00468         );
00469     }
00470 }
00471 
00472 =head2 function_cmp_up_to_constant_abs
00473 
00474     ANS(function_cmp_up_to_constant_abs($correctFunction, $var, $llimit,
00475                                         $ulimit, $absTol, $numOfPoints,
00476                                         $maxConstantOfIntegration));
00477 
00478 function_cmp_up_to_constant_abs() uses antiderivative compare and absolute
00479 tolerance. All but the first argument are optional. $absTol defines the absolute
00480 tolerance value. See the corresponding option to fun_cmp(), above. All other
00481 options work exactly as with function_cmp_up_to_constant().
00482 
00483 =cut
00484 
00485 sub function_cmp_up_to_constant_abs  {  ## for antiderivative problems
00486                                         ## similar to function_cmp_up_to_constant
00487                                         ## but uses absolute tolerance
00488     my ($correctEqn,$var,$llimit,$ulimit,$absTol,$numPoints,$maxConstantOfIntegration) = @_;
00489 
00490     if ( (scalar(@_) == 3) or (scalar(@_) > 7) or (scalar(@_) == 0) ) {
00491         function_invalid_params( $correctEqn );
00492     }
00493 
00494     else {
00495         FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'                    =>  $correctEqn,
00496                 'var'                       =>  $var,
00497                 'limits'                    =>  [$llimit, $ulimit],
00498                 'tolerance'                 =>  $absTol,
00499                 'tolType'                   =>  'absolute',
00500                 'numPoints'                 =>  $numPoints,
00501                 'mode'                      =>  'antider',
00502                 'maxConstantOfIntegration'          =>  $maxConstantOfIntegration,
00503                 'zeroLevel'                 =>  0,
00504                 'zeroLevelTol'                  =>  0
00505         );
00506     }
00507 }
00508 
00509 =head2 adaptive_function_cmp
00510 
00511 FIXME undocumented.
00512 
00513 =cut
00514 
00515 sub adaptive_function_cmp {
00516     my $correctEqn = shift;
00517     my %options = @_;
00518     set_default_options(    \%options,
00519             'vars'          =>  [qw( x y )],
00520                     'params'        =>  [],
00521                     'limits'        =>  [ [0,1], [0,1]],
00522                     'reltol'        =>  $functRelPercentTolDefault,
00523                     'numPoints'     =>  $functNumOfPoints,
00524                     'zeroLevel'     =>  $functZeroLevelDefault,
00525                     'zeroLevelTol'  =>  $functZeroLevelTolDefault,
00526                     'debug'         =>  0,
00527                 'diagnostics'           =>      undef,
00528     );
00529 
00530     my $var_ref = $options{'vars'};
00531     my $ra_params = $options{ 'params'};
00532     my $limit_ref = $options{'limits'};
00533     my $relPercentTol= $options{'reltol'};
00534     my $numPoints = $options{'numPoints'};
00535     my $zeroLevel = $options{'zeroLevel'};
00536     my $zeroLevelTol = $options{'zeroLevelTol'};
00537 
00538     FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'                    =>  $correctEqn,
00539             'var'                       =>  $var_ref,
00540             'limits'                    =>  $limit_ref,
00541             'tolerance'                 =>  $relPercentTol,
00542             'tolType'                   =>  'relative',
00543             'numPoints'                 =>  $numPoints,
00544             'mode'                      =>  'std',
00545             'maxConstantOfIntegration'          =>  10**100,
00546             'zeroLevel'                 =>  $zeroLevel,
00547             'zeroLevelTol'                  =>  $zeroLevelTol,
00548             'scale_norm'                            =>      1,
00549             'params'                                =>      $ra_params,
00550             'debug'                         =>  $options{debug} ,
00551             'diagnostics'                   =>  $options{diagnostics} ,
00552     );
00553 }
00554 
00555 =head1 Multi-variable Function Comparisons
00556 
00557 =head2 [DEPRECATED] multivar_function_cmp
00558 
00559     ANS(multivar_function_cmp($correctFunction, $var, $limits, $relTol, $numPoints, $zeroLevel, $zeroLevelTol));
00560 
00561 This function is deprecated. Use fun_cmp instead:
00562 
00563     ANS(fun_cmp($correctFunction, var=>$var, limits=>$limits, ...));
00564 
00565 =cut
00566 
00567 ## The following answer evaluator for comparing multivarable functions was
00568 ## contributed by Professor William K. Ziemer
00569 ## (Note: most of the multivariable functionality provided by Professor Ziemer
00570 ## has now been integrated into fun_cmp and FUNCTION_CMP)
00571 ############################
00572 # W.K. Ziemer, Sep. 1999
00573 # Math Dept. CSULB
00574 # email: wziemer@csulb.edu
00575 ############################
00576 
00577 sub multivar_function_cmp {
00578     my ($correctEqn,$var_ref,$limit_ref,$relPercentTol,$numPoints,$zeroLevel,$zeroLevelTol) = @_;
00579 
00580     if ( (scalar(@_) > 7) or (scalar(@_) < 2) ) {
00581         function_invalid_params( $correctEqn );
00582     }
00583 
00584     FUNCTION_CMP(   'correctEqn'            =>  $correctEqn,
00585             'var'               =>  $var_ref,
00586             'limits'            =>  $limit_ref,
00587             'tolerance'         =>  $relPercentTol,
00588             'tolType'           =>  'relative',
00589             'numPoints'         =>  $numPoints,
00590             'mode'              =>  'std',
00591             'maxConstantOfIntegration'  =>  0,
00592             'zeroLevel'         =>  $zeroLevel,
00593             'zeroLevelTol'          =>  $zeroLevelTol
00594     );
00595 }
00596 
00597 ## LOW-LEVEL ROUTINE -- NOT NORMALLY FOR END USERS -- USE WITH CAUTION
00598 ## NOTE: PG_answer_eval is used instead of PG_restricted_eval in order to insure that the answer
00599 ## evaluated within the context of the package the problem was originally defined in.
00600 ## Includes multivariable modifications contributed by Professor William K. Ziemer
00601 ##
00602 ## IN:  a hash consisting of the following keys (error checking to be added later?)
00603 ##          correctEqn          --  the correct equation as a string
00604 ##          var             --  the variable name as a string,
00605 ##                              or a reference to an array of variables
00606 ##          limits              --  reference to an array of arrays of type [lower,upper]
00607 ##          tolerance           --  the allowable margin of error
00608 ##          tolType             --  'relative' or 'absolute'
00609 ##          numPoints           --  the number of points to evaluate the function at
00610 ##          mode                --  'std' or 'antider'
00611 ##          maxConstantOfIntegration    --  maximum size of the constant of integration
00612 ##          zeroLevel           --  if the correct answer is this close to zero,
00613 ##                                              then zeroLevelTol applies
00614 ##          zeroLevelTol            --  absolute tolerance to allow when answer is close to zero
00615 ##          test_points         --  user supplied points to use for testing the
00616 ##                          function, either array of arrays, or optionally
00617 ##                          reference to single array (for one variable)
00618 
00619 
00620 sub FUNCTION_CMP {
00621     return ORIGINAL_FUNCTION_CMP(@_)
00622       if $main::useOldAnswerMacros;
00623 
00624     my %func_params = @_;
00625 
00626     my $correctEqn               = $func_params{'correctEqn'};
00627     my $var                      = $func_params{'var'};
00628     my $ra_limits                = $func_params{'limits'};
00629     my $tol                      = $func_params{'tolerance'};
00630     my $tolType                  = $func_params{'tolType'};
00631     my $numPoints                = $func_params{'numPoints'};
00632     my $mode                     = $func_params{'mode'};
00633     my $maxConstantOfIntegration = $func_params{'maxConstantOfIntegration'};
00634     my $zeroLevel                = $func_params{'zeroLevel'};
00635     my $zeroLevelTol             = $func_params{'zeroLevelTol'};
00636     my $testPoints               = $func_params{'test_points'};
00637 
00638     #
00639     #  Check that everything is defined:
00640     #
00641     $func_params{debug} = 0 unless defined $func_params{debug};
00642     $mode = 'std' unless defined $mode;
00643     my @VARS   = get_var_array($var);
00644     my @limits = get_limits_array($ra_limits);
00645     my @PARAMS = @{$func_params{'params'} || []};
00646 
00647     if ($tolType eq 'relative') {
00648       $tol = $functRelPercentTolDefault unless defined $tol;
00649       $tol *= .01;
00650     } else {
00651       $tol = $functAbsTolDefault unless defined $tol;
00652     }
00653 
00654     #
00655     #  Ensure that the number of limits matches number of variables
00656     #
00657     foreach my $i (0..scalar(@VARS)-1) {
00658       $limits[$i][0] = $functLLimitDefault unless defined $limits[$i][0];
00659       $limits[$i][1] = $functULimitDefault unless defined $limits[$i][1];
00660     }
00661 
00662     #
00663     #  Check that the test points are array references with the right number of coordinates
00664     #
00665     if ($testPoints) {
00666       my $n = scalar(@VARS); my $s = ($n != 1)? "s": "";
00667       foreach my $p (@{$testPoints}) {
00668         $p = [$p] unless ref($p) eq 'ARRAY';
00669         warn "Test point (".join(',',@{$p}).") should have $n coordiante$s"
00670           unless scalar(@{$p}) == $n;
00671       }
00672     }
00673 
00674     #
00675     #  Reorder variables, limits, and test_points if the variables are not in alphabetical order
00676     #
00677     if (scalar(@VARS) > 1 && join('',@VARS) ne join('',lex_sort(@VARS))) {
00678       my %order; foreach my $i (0..$#VARS) {$order{$VARS[$i]} = $i}
00679       @VARS = lex_sort(@VARS);
00680       @limits = map {$limits[$order{$_}]} @VARS;
00681       if ($testPoints) {foreach my $p (@{$testPoints}) {$p = [map {$p->[$order{$_}]} @VARS]}}
00682     }
00683 
00684     $numPoints                = $functNumOfPoints              unless defined $numPoints;
00685     $maxConstantOfIntegration = $functMaxConstantOfIntegration unless defined $maxConstantOfIntegration;
00686     $zeroLevel                = $functZeroLevelDefault         unless defined $zeroLevel;
00687     $zeroLevelTol             = $functZeroLevelTolDefault      unless defined $zeroLevelTol;
00688 
00689     $func_params{'var'}                      = \@VARS;
00690         $func_params{'params'}                   = \@PARAMS;
00691     $func_params{'limits'}                   = \@limits;
00692     $func_params{'tolerance'}                = $tol;
00693     $func_params{'tolType'}                  = $tolType;
00694     $func_params{'numPoints'}                = $numPoints;
00695     $func_params{'mode'}                     = $mode;
00696     $func_params{'maxConstantOfIntegration'} = $maxConstantOfIntegration;
00697     $func_params{'zeroLevel'}                = $zeroLevel;
00698     $func_params{'zeroLevelTol'}             = $zeroLevelTol;
00699 
00700     ########################################################
00701     #   End of cleanup of calling parameters
00702     ########################################################
00703 
00704         my %options = (
00705       debug => $func_params{'debug'},
00706           diagnostics => $func_params{'diagnostics'},
00707         );
00708 
00709     #
00710     #  Initialize the context for the formula
00711     #
00712     my $context = Parser::Context->getCopy($user_context,"LegacyNumeric");
00713     $context->flags->set(
00714       tolerance    => $func_params{'tolerance'},
00715       tolType      => $func_params{'tolType'},
00716       zeroLevel    => $func_params{'zeroLevel'},
00717       zeroLevelTol => $func_params{'zeroLevelTol'},
00718       num_points   => $func_params{'numPoints'},
00719     );
00720     if ($func_params{'mode'} eq 'antider') {
00721       $context->flags->set(max_adapt => $func_params{'maxConstantOfIntegration'});
00722       $options{upToConstant} = 1;
00723     }
00724 
00725     #
00726     #  Add the variables and parameters to the context
00727     #
00728     my %variables; my $x;
00729     foreach $x (@{$func_params{'var'}})    {$variables{$x} = 'Real'}
00730     foreach $x (@{$func_params{'params'}}) {$variables{$x} = 'Parameter'}
00731     $context->variables->are(%variables);
00732 
00733     #
00734     #  Create the Formula object and get its answer checker
00735     #
00736     my $oldContext = &$Context(); &$Context($context);
00737     my $f = new Value::Formula($correctEqn);
00738     $f->{limits}      = $func_params{'limits'};
00739     $f->{test_points} = $func_params{'test_points'};
00740         $f->{correct_ans} = $correctEqn;
00741     my $cmp = $f->cmp(%options);
00742     &$Context($oldContext);
00743 
00744     return $cmp;
00745 }
00746 
00747 #
00748 #  The original version, for backward compatibility
00749 #  (can be removed when the Parser-based version is more fully tested.)
00750 #
00751 sub ORIGINAL_FUNCTION_CMP {
00752     my %func_params = @_;
00753     # WARN_MESSAGE("Using ORIGINAL_FUNCTION_CMP subroutine");
00754     my $correctEqn               = $func_params{'correctEqn'};
00755     my $var                      = $func_params{'var'};
00756     my $ra_limits                = $func_params{'limits'};
00757     my $tol                      = $func_params{'tolerance'};
00758     my $tolType                  = $func_params{'tolType'};
00759     my $numPoints                = $func_params{'numPoints'};
00760     my $mode                     = $func_params{'mode'};
00761     my $maxConstantOfIntegration = $func_params{'maxConstantOfIntegration'};
00762     my $zeroLevel                = $func_params{'zeroLevel'};
00763     my $zeroLevelTol             = $func_params{'zeroLevelTol'};
00764     my $ra_test_points           = $func_params{'test_points'};
00765 
00766     # Check that everything is defined:
00767     $func_params{debug} = 0 unless defined $func_params{debug};
00768     $mode = 'std' unless defined $mode;
00769     my @VARS = get_var_array($var);
00770     my @limits = get_limits_array($ra_limits);
00771     my @PARAMS = ();
00772     @PARAMS = @{$func_params{'params'}} if defined $func_params{'params'};
00773 
00774     my @evaluation_points;
00775     if(defined $ra_test_points) {
00776         # see if this is the standard format
00777         if(ref $ra_test_points->[0] eq 'ARRAY') {
00778             $numPoints = scalar @{$ra_test_points->[0]};
00779             # now a little sanity check
00780             my $j;
00781             for $j (@{$ra_test_points}) {
00782                 warn "Test points do not give the same number of values for each variable"
00783                     unless(scalar(@{$j}) == $numPoints);
00784             }
00785             warn "Test points do not match the number of variables"
00786                 unless scalar @{$ra_test_points} == scalar @VARS;
00787         } else { # we are got the one-variable format
00788             $ra_test_points = [$ra_test_points];
00789             $numPoints = scalar $ra_test_points->[0];
00790         }
00791         # The input format for test points is the transpose of what is used
00792         # internally below, so take care of that now.
00793         my ($j1, $j2);
00794         for ($j1 = 0; $j1 < scalar @{$ra_test_points}; $j1++) {
00795             for ($j2 = 0; $j2 < scalar @{$ra_test_points->[$j1]}; $j2++) {
00796                 $evaluation_points[$j2][$j1] = $ra_test_points->[$j1][$j2];
00797             }
00798         }
00799     } # end of handling of user supplied evaluation points
00800 
00801     if ($mode eq 'antider') {
00802         # doctor the equation to allow addition of a constant
00803         my $CONSTANT_PARAM = 'Q'; # unfortunately parameters must be single letters.
00804                                   # There is the possibility of conflict here.
00805                                   #  'Q' seemed less dangerous than  'C'.
00806         $correctEqn = "( $correctEqn ) + $CONSTANT_PARAM";
00807         push @PARAMS, $CONSTANT_PARAM;
00808     }
00809     my $dim_of_param_space = @PARAMS;      # dimension of equivalence space
00810 
00811     if($tolType eq 'relative') {
00812         $tol = $functRelPercentTolDefault unless defined $tol;
00813         $tol *= .01;
00814     } else {
00815         $tol = $functAbsTolDefault unless defined $tol;
00816     }
00817 
00818     #loop ensures that number of limits matches number of variables
00819     for(my $i = 0; $i < scalar @VARS; $i++) {
00820         $limits[$i][0] = $functLLimitDefault unless defined $limits[$i][0];
00821         $limits[$i][1] = $functULimitDefault unless defined $limits[$i][1];
00822     }
00823     $numPoints                = $functNumOfPoints              unless defined $numPoints;
00824     $maxConstantOfIntegration = $functMaxConstantOfIntegration unless defined $maxConstantOfIntegration;
00825     $zeroLevel                = $functZeroLevelDefault         unless defined $zeroLevel;
00826     $zeroLevelTol             = $functZeroLevelTolDefault      unless defined $zeroLevelTol;
00827 
00828     $func_params{'var'}                      = $var;
00829     $func_params{'limits'}                   = \@limits;
00830     $func_params{'tolerance'}                = $tol;
00831     $func_params{'tolType'}                  = $tolType;
00832     $func_params{'numPoints'}                = $numPoints;
00833     $func_params{'mode'}                     = $mode;
00834     $func_params{'maxConstantOfIntegration'} = $maxConstantOfIntegration;
00835     $func_params{'zeroLevel'}                = $zeroLevel;
00836     $func_params{'zeroLevelTol'}             = $zeroLevelTol;
00837 
00838     ########################################################
00839     #   End of cleanup of calling parameters
00840     ########################################################
00841 
00842     my $i; # for use with loops
00843     my $PGanswerMessage = "";
00844     my $originalCorrEqn = $correctEqn;
00845 
00846     ######################################################################
00847     # prepare the correct answer and check its syntax
00848     ######################################################################
00849 
00850     my $rh_correct_ans = new AnswerHash;
00851     $rh_correct_ans->input($correctEqn);
00852     $rh_correct_ans = check_syntax($rh_correct_ans);
00853     warn  $rh_correct_ans->{error_message} if $rh_correct_ans->{error_flag};
00854     $rh_correct_ans->clear_error();
00855     $rh_correct_ans = function_from_string2($rh_correct_ans,
00856         ra_vars => [ @VARS, @PARAMS ],
00857         stdout  => 'rf_correct_ans',
00858         debug   => $func_params{debug}
00859     );
00860     my $correct_eqn_sub = $rh_correct_ans->{rf_correct_ans};
00861     warn $rh_correct_ans->{error_message} if $rh_correct_ans->{error_flag};
00862     
00863     ######################################################################
00864     # define the points at which the functions are to be evaluated
00865     ######################################################################
00866     
00867     if(not defined $ra_test_points) {
00868         #create the evaluation points
00869         my $random_for_answers = new PGrandom($main::PG_original_problemSeed);
00870         my $NUMBER_OF_STEPS_IN_RANDOM = 1000; # determines the granularity of the random_for_answers number generator
00871         for(my $count = 0; $count < @PARAMS+1+$numPoints; $count++) {
00872             my (@vars,$iteration_limit);
00873             for(my $i = 0; $i < @VARS; $i++) {
00874                 my $iteration_limit = 10;
00875                 while (0 < --$iteration_limit) {  # make sure that the endpoints of the interval are not included
00876                     $vars[$i] = $random_for_answers->random($limits[$i][0], $limits[$i][1], abs($limits[$i][1] - $limits[$i][0])/$NUMBER_OF_STEPS_IN_RANDOM);
00877                     last if $vars[$i]!=$limits[$i][0] and $vars[$i]!=$limits[$i][1];
00878                 }
00879                 warn "Unable to properly choose  evaluation points for this function in the interval ( $limits[$i][0] , $limits[$i][1] )"
00880                     if $iteration_limit == 0;
00881             }
00882             
00883             push @evaluation_points, \@vars;
00884         }
00885     }
00886     my $evaluation_points = Matrix->new_from_array_ref(\@evaluation_points);
00887     
00888     #my $COEFFS = determine_param_coeffs($correct_eqn_sub,$evaluation_points[0],$numOfParameters);
00889     #warn "coeff", join(" | ", @{$COEFFS});
00890     
00891     #construct the answer evaluator
00892     my $answer_evaluator = new AnswerEvaluator;
00893     $answer_evaluator->{debug} = $func_params{debug};
00894     $answer_evaluator->ans_hash(    
00895         correct_ans       => $originalCorrEqn,
00896         rf_correct_ans    => $rh_correct_ans->{rf_correct_ans},
00897         evaluation_points => \@evaluation_points,
00898         ra_param_vars     => \@PARAMS,
00899         ra_vars           => \@VARS,
00900         type              => 'function',
00901         score             => 0,
00902     );
00903     
00904     #########################################################
00905     # Prepare the previous answer for evaluation, discard errors
00906     #########################################################
00907     
00908     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(
00909         sub {
00910             my $rh_ans = shift; 
00911                         
00912             $rh_ans->{_filter_name} = "fetch_previous_answer";
00913             $rh_ans->{ans_label}='' unless defined $rh_ans->{ans_label};
00914             my $prev_ans_label = "previous_". $rh_ans->{ans_label};
00915             $rh_ans->{prev_ans} = (defined $inputs_ref->{$prev_ans_label} and $inputs_ref->{$prev_ans_label} =~/\S/)
00916                 ? $inputs_ref->{$prev_ans_label}
00917                 : undef; 
00918             $rh_ans;
00919         }
00920     );
00921     
00922     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(
00923         sub {
00924             my $rh_ans = shift;
00925             return $rh_ans unless defined $rh_ans->{prev_ans};
00926             check_syntax($rh_ans,
00927                 stdin          => 'prev_ans',
00928                 stdout         => 'prev_ans',
00929                 error_msg_flag => 0
00930             );
00931             $rh_ans->{_filter_name} = "check_syntax_of_previous_answer";
00932             $rh_ans;
00933         }
00934     );
00935     
00936     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(
00937         sub {
00938             my $rh_ans = shift;
00939             return $rh_ans unless defined $rh_ans->{prev_ans};
00940             function_from_string2($rh_ans, 
00941                 stdin   => 'prev_ans', 
00942                 stdout  => 'rf_prev_ans',
00943                 ra_vars => \@VARS, 
00944                 debug   => $func_params{debug}
00945             );
00946             $rh_ans->{_filter_name} = "compile_previous_answer";
00947             $rh_ans;
00948         }
00949     );
00950     
00951     #########################################################
00952     # Prepare the current answer for evaluation
00953     #########################################################
00954     
00955     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&check_syntax);
00956     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&function_from_string2,
00957         ra_vars => \@VARS,
00958         debug   => $func_params{debug}
00959     ); # @VARS has been guaranteed to be an array, $var might be a single string.
00960     
00961     #########################################################
00962     # Compare the previous and current answer.  Discard errors
00963     #########################################################
00964     
00965     $answer_evaluator->install_evaluator(
00966         sub {
00967             my $rh_ans = shift;
00968             return $rh_ans unless defined $rh_ans->{rf_prev_ans};
00969             calculate_difference_vector($rh_ans, 
00970                 %func_params, 
00971                 stdin1         => 'rf_student_ans', 
00972                 stdin2         => 'rf_prev_ans',
00973                 stdout         => 'ra_diff_with_prev_ans',
00974                 error_msg_flag => 0,
00975             );
00976             $rh_ans->{_filter_name} = "calculate_difference_vector_of_previous_answer";
00977             $rh_ans;
00978         }
00979     );
00980     
00981     $answer_evaluator->install_evaluator(
00982         sub {
00983             my $rh_ans = shift;
00984             return $rh_ans unless defined $rh_ans->{ra_diff_with_prev_ans};
00985             ##
00986             ## DPVC -- only give the message if the answer is specified differently
00987             ##
00988             return $rh_ans if $rh_ans->{prev_ans} eq $rh_ans->{student_ans};
00989             ##
00990             ## /DPVC
00991             ##
00992             is_zero_array($rh_ans,
00993                 stdin  => 'ra_diff_with_prev_ans', 
00994                 stdout => 'ans_equals_prev_ans' 
00995             );
00996         }
00997     );
00998     
00999     #########################################################
01000     # Calculate values for approximation parameters and
01001     # compare the current answer with the correct answer.  Keep errors this time.
01002     #########################################################
01003    
01004     $answer_evaluator->install_pre_filter(\&best_approx_parameters, %func_params, param_vars => \@PARAMS);
01005     $answer_evaluator->install_evaluator(\&calculate_difference_vector, %func_params);
01006     $answer_evaluator->install_evaluator(\&is_zero_array, tolerance => $tol );
01007 
01008     $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(
01009         sub {
01010             my $rh_ans = shift;
01011             $rh_ans->clear_error('SYNTAX');
01012             $rh_ans;
01013         }
01014     );
01015     
01016     $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(
01017         sub {
01018             my $rh_ans = shift;
01019             if ($rh_ans->catch_error('EVAL')) {
01020                 $rh_ans->{ans_message} = $rh_ans->{error_message};
01021                 $rh_ans->clear_error('EVAL');
01022             }
01023             $rh_ans;
01024         }
01025     );
01026     
01027     #
01028     #  Show a message when the answer is equivalent to the previous answer.
01029     #  
01030     #  We want to show the message when we're not in preview mode AND the
01031     #  answers are equivalent AND the answers are not identical. We DON'T CARE
01032     #  whether the answers are correct or not, because that leaks information in
01033     #  multipart questions when $showPartialCorrectAnswers is off.
01034     #
01035     $answer_evaluator->install_post_filter(
01036         sub {
01037             my $rh_ans = shift; 
01038             #WARN_MESSAGE(pretty_print($inputs_ref));
01039             my $isPreview = $inputs_ref->{previewAnswers}; # || ($inputs_ref->{action} =~ m/^Preview/);
01040             return $rh_ans unless !$isPreview # not preview mode
01041                 and $rh_ans->{ans_equals_prev_ans} # equivalent
01042                 and $rh_ans->{prev_ans} ne $rh_ans->{original_student_ans}; # not identical
01043             
01044             $rh_ans->{ans_message} = "This answer is equivalent to the one you just submitted.";
01045             return $rh_ans;
01046         }
01047     );
01048     
01049     $answer_evaluator;
01050 }
